Jinnō Shōtōki, p. 164-165. == Events of the Jōwa era == There were disturbances when Emperor Junna abdicated; and this time was called Jōwa no Hen.Nussbaum, "Jōwa no Hen" at p. 434. * 834 (Jōwa 1): Emperor Ninmyō planted a cherry tree near the shishinden to replace the tree Emperor Kammu planted when the capital of Japan was moved to Heian-kyō (Kyoto).Ponsonby-Fane, Richard. (1956). Kyoto: the Old Capital of Japan, p. 63. * 834 (Jōwa 1): Kukai was permitted to create a Buddhist chapel at the Imperial Palace.Kukai. (1972). Kūkai: Major Works (S. Hakeda, editor), p. 59. * 11 June 840 (Jōwa 7, 8th day of the 5th month): Former-Emperor Junna died at the age of 55.Brown, [https://books.google.com/books?id=w4f5FrmIJKIC&pg;=PA284 p. 284; Imperial Household Agency (Kunaichō): 淳和天皇 (53); retrieved 2011-12-27. * 841 (Jōwa 8, 11th month): A broom star was seen in the west.Pankenier, David et al. (2008). Archaeoastronomy in East Asia: Historical Observational Records of Comets and Meteor Showers from China, Japan, and Korea, p. 98. * 24 August 842 (Jōwa 9, 15th day of the 7th month): Former-Emperor Saga died at the age of 57.Brown, p. 282; Varley, p. 163; Kunaichō, 嵯峨天皇 (52); retrieved 2012-5-22. * 843 (Jōwa 10): Work was completed on the Nihon kōki.Nussbaum, "Nihon Kōki" at p. 709.
